N.Wells
No. They are perfectly capable of convincing themselves of lies, distortions, and silliness, even about rocks as spectacularly exposed as those in the Grand Canyon.
Mucusaur

Amazing what basic principals, easily observable in the field, people can be convinced are false. 
 
 Is the observation that sediment sorting occurs according to surface area and density? (silt and mud staying in suspension longer than sand grains)
 
 Is the observation that sediments deposited at different rates and different environments show different characteristics? (Hummocky cross stratification in storms beach settings, turbidites in marine settings)
 
 These simply observed principals were enough to convince the early scientist that the earth must be immeasurably old, even before the days of geochronometry and radiometric decay techniques. Yes they can be misinterpreted, but we have yet to see a creationist explain how a several Km sequence of ponded turbdite flows or the superimposition of of one sedimentological environment atop a vastly different one argues convincingly for a young earth.

post_info.post_title: But Feindslayer is an honorable man

feindslayer

Is the observation that sediment sorting occurs according to surface area and density? (silt and mud staying in suspension longer than sand grains)
 
 Is the observation that sediments deposited at different rates and different environments show different characteristics? (Hummocky cross stratification in storms beach settings, turbidites in marine settings)
 
 These simply observed principals were enough to convince the early scientist that the earth must be immeasurably old, even before the days of geochronometry and radiometric decay techniques. Yes they can be misinterpreted, but we have yet to see a creationist explain how a several Km sequence of ponded turbdite flows or the superimposition of of one sedimentological environment atop a vastly different one argues convincingly for a young earth. 

 
 The first point is true, but that does not prove the Earth's age. I did an experiment, just to make sure. I mixed up different sediments and items with different densities in churning water, to simulate the Genesis Flood (which is another debate altogether). When I was done, it only took about an hour for the sediment to settle completely with the densest sediment at the bottom and the least dense at the top.
 
 This second point can also be explained by the Genesis flood. The waters were strong enough to churn everything so much that everything got completely mixed up.

 Wow, how much sugar did you have today? One at a time now:

chemist99a

Can't get someone to believe you? Just make up some lies, get them backed by our tax dollars, and call it science. It's the evolutionist way of doing it

 
 Nope thats the creationist approach - to substitute raw political power for the scientific search for truth (or a better approximation of truth). One can see it rather badly done by the current administration in Washington.
Mucusaur

The first point is true, but that does not prove the Earth's age. I did an experiment, just to make sure. I mixed up different sediments and items with different densities in churning water, to simulate the Genesis Flood (which is another debate altogether). When I was done, it only took about an hour for the sediment to settle completely with the densest sediment at the bottom and the least dense at the top.

 
 What does this prove - sediment settles in the presence of gravity. You say that this correlates with flood - sure fine atop coarse. But throughout the world there are many beds where we find this type of grading repeated in the stratigraphy, such as the upwards fining beds of the Tabernas basin in Spain, or the Upwards fining oolitic shoals of the Wessex-Weald basin. How are there numerous of these events? Were there thousands of floods in the past 6000 years?
 
 
 
This second point can also be explained by the Genesis flood. The waters were strong enough to churn everything so much that everything got completely mixed up.

 
 Hummocky cross stratification like most bed forms are not formed by a chaotic dumping or churning of sediment, but by a regular flow regime. In this case, hummocks are formed by the base of waves in the storm.washed part of the beach. The formation of bedforms is a well understood process, used commonly by the nice people in the oil industry to determine reservoir setting and hence to deduce oil reservoir porosity. You would NOT find them in a flood deposit. The flood is not a catch all explanation for any sedimentary structure you like. 
 
 You assume a flood caused by the graduall accumulation of rainwater would be erosive and would churn up vast quantities of sediment? Why? I Would expect the only result of a huge body of standing water on the earths surface to be a thin, fine grained band of marine sediment, more or less free of any sedimentary structure, but full of a chaotic assemblage of both marine and terrestrial fauna, found across the world. 
 
 Needless to say, we do not find this. 
 
 Geological evidence for the Flood - none
chemist99a
